best_practices: Always extend BaseController for consistent error handling and Sentry integration
Use dependency injection for services to enable easy testing and mocking
Validate all inputs with Zod schemas before processing
Never access Prisma directly from controllers - always use repositories
anti_patterns: Putting business logic in route handlers - keep routes thin
Using process.env directly - use unifiedConfig instead
Creating god services that handle everything - keep services focused
Forgetting to add Sentry error tracking - all errors must be captured

faq.question: Can I use this with other ORMs besides Prisma?
faq.answer: The patterns work with any ORM, but examples use Prisma. Adapt repository methods to your ORM's syntax.

faq.question: Do I need all these layers for simple CRUD?
faq.answer: For simple operations, you can skip repositories and call Prisma from services. Add repositories when queries get complex.

faq.question: How do I test controllers that extend BaseController?
faq.answer: Mock the BaseController methods or test at the service level instead. Focus integration tests on HTTP layer.

faq.question: What's the performance impact of all these layers?
faq.answer: Minimal overhead in Node.js. The maintainability benefits far outweigh any slight performance cost.

faq.question: Can I use these patterns with NestJS?
faq.answer: Yes, the concepts transfer well. NestJS has built-in DI and decorators that can replace some manual patterns.

faq.question: How do I handle transactions across multiple services?
faq.answer: Use Prisma's transaction API in your service layer, calling multiple repositories within a single transaction.
